expressions.definition: To avoid talking about what is important or to delay coming to the main point.
examples: When asked about the company's future plans, the CEO beat around the bush and didn't give a clear answer.
Stop beating around the bush and tell me what you really think.
The politician was accused of beating around the bush during the interview instead of addressing the issues directly.
I wish you wouldn't beat around the bush and just say what's on your mind.
She tends to beat around the bush when she's nervous about giving bad news.
expressions.context: This expression is used when someone is avoiding the main topic or not speaking directly about an issue. It is often used in informal contexts to encourage someone to be more direct.

spanish.definition: Evitar hablar de lo que es importante o retrasar llegar al punto principal.

expressions.definition: To worry excessively about minor or unimportant details.
examples: Don't sweat the small stuff; focus on the bigger picture instead.
She tends to sweat the small stuff, which often causes unnecessary stress.
If you sweat the small stuff, you'll never have time to enjoy life.
He learned not to sweat the small stuff after realizing it wasn't worth the anxiety.
Try not to sweat the small stuff when planning the event; everything will work out fine.
expressions.context: This expression is used to advise someone not to worry about trivial matters and to focus on more important issues. It is often used in informal settings.

spanish.definition: Preocuparse excesivamente por detalles menores o sin importancia.

expressions.definition: To stop working on something, typically because the work is finished or because it is time to stop for the day.
examples: After finishing the report, we decided to call it a day and go home.
It's getting late, so let's call it a day and continue tomorrow.
We've done enough for today; let's call it a day.
The team agreed to call it a day after the successful meeting.
Once the sun set, the farmers called it a day and headed back to their homes.
expressions.context: This expression is commonly used in informal settings, often in workplaces or situations where a task or activity is being concluded for the day.

spanish.definition: Dejar de trabajar en algo, generalmente porque el trabajo está terminado o porque es hora de parar por el día.

expressions.definition: To be the person who makes the important decisions in a situation or organization.
examples: In this company, the CEO calls the shots, so we need to get his approval before proceeding.
During the meeting, it was clear that Sarah was the one calling the shots.
Even though he is new to the team, he quickly started calling the shots on the project.
The coach calls the shots on the field, and the players follow his strategy.
In our household, my mom calls the shots when it comes to family vacations.
expressions.context: This expression is used in informal contexts to indicate who has the authority or control in a particular situation. It is often used in workplaces, teams, or any group setting where decisions need to be made.

spanish.definition: Ser la persona que toma las decisiones importantes en una situación u organización.
spanish.expression: Yo tengo la última palabra aquí

expressions.definition: This expression means that someone is about to leave a place or is in the process of leaving.
examples: I just wanted to say goodbye because I'm on my way out.
Sorry, I can't talk right now; I'm on my way out the door.
I'm on my way out, but I'll call you when I get home.
She was on her way out when she remembered she forgot her keys.
I'm on my way out to meet some friends for dinner.
expressions.context: This expression is commonly used in informal settings to indicate that someone is leaving or about to leave a location. It can be used in both personal and professional contexts.

spanish.definition: Esta expresión significa que alguien está a punto de salir de un lugar o está en el proceso de salir.

expressions.definition: Stop complaining or expressing dissatisfaction in an annoying way.
examples: When the kids started to complain about the long car ride, their father told them to quit their whining.
If you don't like the rules, you can try to change them, but quit your whining in the meantime.
She was tired of hearing her colleague complain about the workload and finally said, 'Quit your whining and just get it done.'
The coach told the team to quit their whining and focus on improving their skills.
After listening to his friend complain about the weather for an hour, he finally said, 'Quit your whining, it's just a bit of rain.'
expressions.context: This expression is used in informal contexts to tell someone to stop complaining or expressing dissatisfaction, especially when it is perceived as excessive or annoying.

spanish.definition: Deja de quejarte o expresar insatisfacción de manera molesta.

expressions.definition: To accompany someone, especially when not invited or when it is not necessary.
examples: I didn't have any plans for the weekend, so I decided to tag along with my friends to the beach.
Whenever my sister goes shopping, I like to tag along to see what's new in the stores.
He wasn't originally part of the group, but he tagged along and ended up having a great time.
Do you mind if I tag along to the concert? I love that band!
The kids always tag along with their parents when they go to the park.
expressions.context: This expression is used in informal contexts to describe joining someone or a group, often spontaneously or without prior invitation. It is commonly used in social situations.

spanish.definition: Acompañar a alguien, especialmente cuando no se ha sido invitado o no es necesario.

expressions.definition: This expression is used when someone you have just been talking about unexpectedly appears.
examples: We were just discussing the new manager, and speak of the devil, here she comes!
I was telling my friend about my brother's new job, and speak of the devil, he called me right then.
Speak of the devil! I was just about to call you.
We were talking about our old teacher, and speak of the devil, she walked into the café.
Speak of the devil, we were just mentioning your name!
expressions.context: This expression is often used in informal conversations when someone appears just after being mentioned. It is typically used in a light-hearted or humorous context.

spanish.definition: Esta expresión se usa cuando alguien de quien acabas de hablar aparece inesperadamente.

expressions.definition: To report someone's wrongdoing or secret to an authority or another person.
examples: If you tell on me for breaking the vase, I'll be in big trouble with Mom.
She was worried that her friend would tell on her for skipping class.
Please don't tell on me; I promise I'll fix it before anyone notices.
He threatened to tell on me if I didn't share my lunch with him.
The teacher asked the students not to tell on each other for minor mistakes.
expressions.context: This expression is often used in informal contexts, especially among children or in situations where someone might report another's misbehavior to an authority figure.

spanish.definition: Informar sobre la mala conducta o el secreto de alguien a una autoridad u otra persona.

chat.content:
¡Claro! Aquí tienes un ejemplo de cómo podrías usar "you tell on me" en una conversación:

**Contexto:** Dos amigos, Alex y Jamie, están hablando después de que Alex hizo una travesura en clase.

---

**Alex:** Hey, Jamie, I can't believe I knocked over the teacher's coffee mug today.

**Jamie:** Yeah, that was quite the spill! Are you worried about getting in trouble?

**Alex:** A little. But please, don't tell on me, okay? I'll clean it up tomorrow.

**Jamie:** Don't worry, I won't tell on you. Just be careful next time!

---

En este diálogo, *"don't tell on me"* significa que Alex le está pidiendo a Jamie que no le cuente a la maestra sobre el incidente. ¿Te queda más claro ahora?

expressions.definition: A quality or charm that remains attractive and relevant regardless of the passage of time.
examples: The little black dress has a timeless appeal that makes it a staple in every woman's wardrobe.
Classical music has a timeless appeal that continues to captivate audiences around the world.
The novel's timeless appeal lies in its universal themes of love and loss.
Despite being over a century old, the painting's timeless appeal draws visitors from all over the globe.
The architecture of the ancient city has a timeless appeal that fascinates historians and tourists alike.
expressions.context: This expression is often used to describe things like fashion, art, literature, or music that remain popular and admired over long periods. It suggests that the item or concept is not subject to the whims of trends or time.

spanish.definition: Una cualidad o encanto que sigue siendo atractivo y relevante independientemente del paso del tiempo.

chat.content:
¡Claro! Aquí tienes un ejemplo de cómo podrías usar la expresión "timeless appeal" en una conversación real.

---

**Contexto:** Estás hablando con un amigo sobre películas clásicas.

**Amigo:** I watched "Casablanca" last night. It's such an old movie, but I loved it!

**Tú:** I know, right? "Casablanca" has a **timeless appeal**. The story and the characters are just as captivating today as they were back then.

---

En este ejemplo, "timeless appeal" se usa para describir una película que sigue siendo atractiva y relevante a pesar de ser antigua. ¿Te gustaría otro ejemplo o alguna aclaración más?

expressions.definition: Residing in a house or apartment that is immediately adjacent to another.
examples: I've been living next door to my best friend for over ten years.
The family living next door always throws the best parties.
We didn't know anyone when we moved in, but the couple living next door introduced themselves right away.
Living next door to a bakery means I wake up to the smell of fresh bread every morning.
The noise from the construction site next door is quite bothersome.
expressions.context: This expression is used to describe the physical proximity of one's residence to another's. It is commonly used in everyday conversation to talk about neighbors or nearby locations.

spanish.definition: Residir en una casa o apartamento que está inmediatamente al lado de otro.

expressions.definition: To act or plan too ambitiously or prematurely, often without considering all the necessary steps or details.
examples: She started buying baby clothes before she was even pregnant, really getting ahead of herself.
Don't get ahead of yourself by planning the vacation before you know if you can take time off work.
He got ahead of himself and started the project without the necessary approvals.
The team got ahead of themselves by celebrating the victory before the game was over.
You shouldn't get ahead of yourself by assuming you'll get the job before the interview.
expressions.context: This expression is used to caution someone against making premature decisions or assumptions. It often implies that someone is overly eager or optimistic about future events without considering the present situation.

spanish.definition: Actuar o planear de manera demasiado ambiciosa o prematura, a menudo sin considerar todos los pasos o detalles necesarios.

expressions.definition: There is potential for improvement or development in a particular area.
examples: The company has been doing well, but there's room for growth in the international market.
Although her skills are impressive, there's room for growth in her leadership abilities.
The garden looks beautiful, but there's room for growth if we add more flowers.
The project is successful, but there's room for growth in terms of efficiency.
His performance was good, but there's room for growth in his public speaking skills.
expressions.context: This expression is used to indicate that while something is satisfactory, it can still be improved or expanded. It is often used in professional, educational, or personal development contexts.

spanish.definition: Hay potencial para mejorar o desarrollarse en un área particular.

chat.content: ¿Tiene  mas significados que el que me diste?

La expresión "there's room for growth" se utiliza principalmente para indicar que hay potencial para mejorar o desarrollarse en un área particular. Este es su significado principal. Sin embargo, se puede aplicar a diferentes contextos, como:

- **Personal**: "In your English skills, there's room for growth." Esto sugiere que tienes la capacidad de mejorar tu nivel de inglés.
- **Profesional**: "In your career, there's room for growth." Esto indica que hay oportunidades para avanzar o mejorar en tu trabajo.
- **Empresarial**: "In this market, there's room for growth." Esto significa que hay potencial para que el negocio se expanda.

Así que, aunque el significado básico es el mismo, puede aplicarse a diferentes situaciones para indicar la posibilidad de mejora o desarrollo.

expressions.definition: Repeatedly or frequently over a period of time.
examples: Time and again, she has proven herself to be a reliable friend.
The teacher reminded the students time and again to submit their assignments on time.
Time and again, the company has shown its commitment to quality.
He has been warned time and again about the dangers of smoking.
Time and again, history has shown us the importance of learning from past mistakes.
expressions.context: This expression is used to emphasize the frequency or regularity of an action or event. It is often used in both formal and informal contexts to highlight persistence or repetition.

spanish.definition: Repetidamente o con frecuencia durante un período de tiempo.

chat.content:
¡Claro! Aquí tienes cinco ejemplos de cómo usar la expresión "time and again" en inglés:

### Meaning
- "Time and again" significa **repeatedly** o **frequently** a lo largo de un período de tiempo.

### Examples
- **Time and again**, she has proven her dedication to the project.
- The teacher reminded the students **time and again** to submit their assignments on time.
- **Time and again**, he forgot to lock the door before leaving the house.
- Despite his promises **time and again**, he never followed through.
- **Time and again**, the team has shown they can win under pressure.

### Mini dialogues
- **A:** Why do you keep checking the door lock?
- **B:** Because **time and again**, I've forgotten to lock it.

- **A:** Have you talked to the manager about the issue?
- **B:** Yes, **time and again**, but nothing has changed.

### Synonyms/Alternatives
- **Repeatedly**
- **Again and again**
- **Over and over**

### Usage notes
- **Register**: Neutral, can be used in both formal and informal contexts.
- **Tone**: Often used to emphasize frustration or persistence.
- **Typical collocations**: "Time and again" is often followed by actions like *remind*, *prove*, *show*, *forget*.

### Common mistakes
- Avoid using "time and again" to describe a **single event**. It's used for actions that happen **multiple times**.
- Do not confuse with "from time to time," which means **occasionally**.

Espero que estos ejemplos y notas te sean útiles para entender y usar "time and again" correctamente. ¡Sigue practicando!

expressions.expression: This week went badly for me
expressions.definition: This expression is used to describe a week in which things did not go as planned or were unfavorable for the speaker.
examples: After missing my train and losing my wallet, I can definitely say this week went badly for me.
This week went badly for me because I caught a cold and had to miss work.
I had a lot of unexpected expenses, so this week went badly for me financially.
This week went badly for me as I failed my driving test and had an argument with my friend.
With all the deadlines and stress, this week went badly for me.
expressions.context: This expression is typically used in informal conversations to express dissatisfaction or disappointment about how the events of the week unfolded.

spanish.definition: Esta expresión se utiliza para describir una semana en la que las cosas no salieron como se planeó o fueron desfavorables para el hablante.

expressions.definition: Used to indicate that something is not logical or does not make sense.
examples: She said she was at home all night, but her story doesn't add up because I saw her at the party.
The numbers in the report don't add up, so we need to double-check the calculations.
His explanation for being late doesn't add up; I think he's hiding something.
If the evidence doesn't add up, the jury might not convict the defendant.
The expenses listed in the budget don't add up to the total amount claimed.
expressions.context: This expression is commonly used in informal contexts to express doubt or skepticism about the truth or logic of a statement or situation.

spanish.definition: Usado para indicar que algo no es lógico o no tiene sentido.

expressions.expression: you get what you pay for
expressions.definition: This expression means that the quality of something is usually reflected in its price; if you pay little, you should expect lower quality.
examples: I bought a cheap phone, but it broke after a month. I guess you get what you pay for.
She decided to invest in a more expensive laptop because she believes you get what you pay for.
When it comes to hiring professionals, remember that you get what you pay for.
He was disappointed with the service at the budget hotel, but you get what you pay for.
I tried the discount brand of shoes, but they wore out quickly. You get what you pay for.
expressions.context: This expression is often used in informal contexts to explain or justify why something inexpensive may not meet expectations in terms of quality or performance. It is commonly used in consumer situations.

spanish.definition: Esta expresión significa que la calidad de algo generalmente se refleja en su precio; si pagas poco, debes esperar menor calidad.

expressions.definition: Something that is more complex or interesting than it initially appears.
examples: The situation was more complicated than what meets the eye.
There is more to the story than what meets the eye.
The painting seems simple, but there's more to it than what meets the eye.
Her calm demeanor hides more than what meets the eye.
The book is deeper than what meets the eye at first glance.
expressions.context: This expression is used to suggest that there is more to a situation, person, or thing than is immediately apparent. It is often used to encourage looking beyond the surface.

spanish.definition: Algo que es más complejo o interesante de lo que parece a simple vista.
spanish.expression: más de lo que parece a simple vista

expressions.definition: A euphemistic way of explaining the basic facts about sex and reproduction to children.
examples: When I was ten, my parents sat me down to talk about the birds and the bees.
Teachers often struggle with how to introduce the topic of the birds and the bees in a classroom setting.
I remember my awkward conversation with my dad about the birds and the bees.
Some parents use books to help explain the birds and the bees to their children.
It's important to discuss the birds and the bees with kids in an age-appropriate way.
expressions.context: This expression is typically used in informal settings when referring to the conversation about sex education, especially with children. It is often used to avoid directly mentioning sex.

spanish.definition: Una forma eufemística de explicar los conceptos básicos sobre el sexo y la reproducción a los niños.

expressions.definition: To annoy or irritate someone persistently.
examples: My little brother always bugs me when I'm trying to do my homework.
It really bugs me when people talk loudly on their phones in public places.
She was bugged by the constant noise from the construction site next door.
Stop bugging me about going to the gym; I'll go when I'm ready.
His habit of interrupting others during meetings bugs everyone in the office.
expressions.context: This expression is used in informal contexts to describe a situation where someone is being persistently annoying or irritating. It is commonly used in everyday conversation.

spanish.definition: Molestar o irritar a alguien persistentemente.

expressions.definition: An expression used to describe something or someone as excellent or of high quality.
examples: That new restaurant is the bee’s knees; the food was amazing!
My grandmother thinks her homemade cookies are the bee’s knees.
After trying several brands, I found this shampoo to be the bee’s knees for my hair.
He believes his new car is the bee’s knees and loves showing it off.
The concert last night was the bee’s knees; I had such a great time!
expressions.context: This expression is often used in informal settings to compliment or praise something or someone. It conveys a sense of admiration and approval.

spanish.definition: Una expresión utilizada para describir algo o alguien como excelente o de alta calidad.

expressions.definition: A humorous or informal way to say that something is not someone else's business or concern.
examples: When she asked about my salary, I told her it was none of her beeswax.
He kept prying into my personal life, so I had to remind him that it was none of his beeswax.
If they ask about our plans for the weekend, just tell them it's none of their beeswax.
I overheard them talking about my project, but I decided it was none of my beeswax to interfere.
She wanted to know why I was late, but I said it was none of her beeswax.
expressions.context: This expression is used in informal settings to tell someone that they should not be concerned with or involved in a particular matter. It is often used in a light-hearted or humorous way.

spanish.definition: Una forma humorística o informal de decir que algo no es asunto o preocupación de otra persona.

chat.content: hay otra manera de decier esto ,, algo con what

¡Claro! Veamos la expresión "none of one's beeswax" y cómo se relaciona con otras frases en inglés.

### Meaning
La expresión **"none of one's beeswax"** significa que algo no es asunto o preocupación de alguien más. Es una forma humorística o informal de decir que alguien no debe entrometerse.

### Usage notes
- **Register**: Es informal y algo juguetona.
- **Tone**: Se usa para ser gracioso o ligero, no ofensivo.
- **Typical collocations**: Se usa frecuentemente en conversaciones casuales.

### Examples
- "That's none of your beeswax!"
- "When she asked about my salary, I told her it was none of her beeswax."
- "It's really none of his beeswax what I do on weekends."
- "Why do you care? It's none of your beeswax."
- "She needs to understand that my personal life is none of her beeswax."

### Mini dialogues
**Dialogue 1:**
- **Person A**: "Why didn't you go to the party last night?"
- **Person B**: "That's none of your beeswax!"

**Dialogue 2:**
- **Person A**: "How much did you pay for your new car?"
- **Person B**: "Sorry, that's none of your beeswax."

### Synonyms/Alternatives
- "None of your business"
- "Mind your own business"
- "It's not your concern"
- "What does it matter to you?"

### Common mistakes
- Avoid using it in formal settings; it's best for casual conversations.
- Be cautious not to offend someone; ensure the context is light-hearted.

La expresión que buscas con "what" podría ser "What does it matter to you?" que también implica que algo no es asunto de la otra persona.

expressions.definition: To tease or joke with someone by making them believe something that is not true.
examples: When he said he won the lottery, I knew he was just pulling my leg.
Don't worry, I'm just pulling your leg about the surprise party.
She told me she saw a UFO, but I think she's pulling my leg.
He said he met a celebrity at the grocery store, but I suspect he's pulling my leg.
Are you pulling my leg, or did you really get a pet tiger?
expressions.context: This expression is used in informal settings when someone is joking or teasing another person by making them believe something that is not true. It is often used in a light-hearted manner.

spanish.definition: Bromear o tomar el pelo a alguien haciéndole creer algo que no es cierto.

expressions.definition: To be an unnoticed observer of a particular situation or event.
examples: I wish I could be a fly on the wall during their meeting to hear what they really think.
As a fly on the wall, she learned a lot about the company's future plans.
He wanted to be a fly on the wall when his favorite band was recording their new album.
Imagine being a fly on the wall in the courtroom during that famous trial.
She felt like a fly on the wall at the party, listening to all the interesting conversations.
expressions.context: This expression is used when someone wants to observe a situation without being noticed, often to gain insight or information that is not publicly available.

spanish.definition: Ser un observador desapercibido de una situación o evento particular.
spanish.expression: ser una mosca en la pared

expressions.definition: Very comfortable and cozy, often in a small or confined space.
examples: After tucking her into bed, she looked as snug as a bug in her warm blankets.
The puppy curled up in its basket, looking as snug as a bug.
With the heater on, the cabin felt as snug as a bug during the snowstorm.
He wrapped himself in the thick quilt and felt as snug as a bug.
The children were as snug as a bug in their sleeping bags during the camping trip.
expressions.context: This expression is used to describe someone who is very comfortable and warm, often in a cozy or small space. It is informal and often used in friendly or familial settings.

spanish.definition: Muy cómodo y acogedor, a menudo en un espacio pequeño o confinado.

expressions.definition: To achieve something with great success or distinction.
examples: She passed her final exams with flying colors, scoring the highest marks in her class.
The team completed the project with flying colors, impressing the management with their efficiency.
After months of training, he finished the marathon with flying colors, setting a personal best time.
The new product launch went off with flying colors, exceeding all sales expectations.
Despite the challenges, she defended her thesis with flying colors and received her degree.
expressions.context: This expression is used to describe a situation where someone has succeeded or performed exceptionally well, often in an exam, test, or challenge.

spanish.definition: Lograr algo con gran éxito o distinción.

expressions.definition: To reconcile or make peace after an argument or disagreement, often implying a return to a friendly or romantic relationship.
examples: After their big fight last night, they decided to kiss and wake up this morning.
It's normal for couples to argue, but it's important to kiss and wake up afterward.
They had a misunderstanding, but they managed to kiss and wake up before the day ended.
Even though they disagreed on many things, they always found a way to kiss and wake up.
The siblings had a heated argument, but they kissed and woke up by the next family dinner.
expressions.context: This expression is used in informal contexts to describe the act of making up after a disagreement, especially in personal relationships. It suggests a positive resolution and a return to normalcy.

spanish.definition: Reconciliarse o hacer las paces después de una discusión o desacuerdo, a menudo implicando un regreso a una relación amistosa o romántica.

expressions.definition: To forget past disagreements or grievances and move on without holding grudges.
examples: After their argument, they decided to let bygones be bygones and became friends again.
It's time to let bygones be bygones and focus on the future.
They had a long discussion and agreed to let bygones be bygones for the sake of the team.
Even though they had a rough past, they chose to let bygones be bygones and work together.
She apologized for her mistakes, and he was willing to let bygones be bygones.
expressions.context: This expression is used when people want to forgive and forget past conflicts or issues, often to improve relationships or move forward positively.

spanish.definition: Olvidar desacuerdos o agravios pasados y seguir adelante sin guardar rencores.

expressions.definition: A question asked when someone is silent or unresponsive, suggesting they are at a loss for words.
examples: When I asked him about the surprise party, he just stood there. Cat got your tongue?
She didn't say anything during the meeting. It was like the cat got her tongue.
After hearing the shocking news, he was speechless. I joked, 'Cat got your tongue?'
Whenever she's nervous, it's as if the cat's got her tongue.
He usually has a lot to say, but today it seems the cat got his tongue.
expressions.context: This expression is used in informal settings when someone is unusually quiet or seems unable to speak. It is often used humorously or teasingly.

spanish.definition: Una pregunta que se hace cuando alguien está en silencio o no responde, sugiriendo que no sabe qué decir.

expressions.definition: To get to the point without wasting time on unnecessary details.
examples: Let's cut to the chase and discuss the main issue at hand.
I don't have much time, so I'll cut to the chase: we need to improve our sales strategy.
After a long introduction, the speaker finally cut to the chase and presented the key findings.
Can we cut to the chase? I need to know if you're interested in the job offer.
Instead of beating around the bush, she cut to the chase and told him the truth.
expressions.context: This expression is often used in informal settings when someone wants to focus on the most important part of a conversation or presentation without unnecessary details.

spanish.definition: Ir al grano sin perder tiempo en detalles innecesarios.
